By: FE Online | New Delhi | Updated: March 26, 2017 12:11 PM PM Narendra Modi said manifests the strength and skills of 125 crore Indians, who will create a Bhavya and Divya Bharat. (Source: PTI) 
On Sunday morning, Prime Minister Narendra Modi held the 30th episode of his radio show ‘Mann Ki Baat’. While in his previous episodes, he has talked about the pressure of board exams and appreciated the efforts of individuals who contributed to the success of ‘Swachch Bharat Abhiyan’, this time the PM talked about various topics ranging from Bangladesh’s Independence Day to depression among people. One of the striking points of his speech was the mention of ‘New India’, a concept that Bharatiya Janata Party has recently introduced for taking India ahead.

In 26th March’s episode, PM Modi said, “New India is not a government scheme or a matter of politics. It manifests the strength and skills of 125 crore Indians, who will create a Bhavya and Divya Bharat.” He added that New India is a dream of every citizen of India and if we take one step at a time, this dream can turn into a reality. PM Modi also thanked people for showing great support for digital transactions. He said, “India has extended support to the movement towards digital transactions. People of India have rejected corruption and black money .” 
The concept of ‘New India’ was first introduced by the Prime Minister after Bharatiya Janata Party’s massive victory in the Uttar Pradesh assembly elections. While addressing the party leaders at the BJP office, he thanked the voters by saying results of these five states is the foundation for a new India. “I would like to thank the voters of the five states, want to assure them that we will leave no stone unturned for the betterment. Through the membership drive, the BJP has been able to become the largest political party in the world,” said PM Modi. 
While remembering the contribution of freedom fighters like Bhagat Singh, Sukhdev and Rajguru, PM Modi said, “Bhagat Singh, Sukhdev and Rajguru were not scared of death. They lived and died for our nation.” He added that these icons are still an inspiration for youth.
